creditline: Gift of the Clark Center for Japanese Art & Culture
description: crooked tree with two entangled trunks at center; monkey in branches at UR, another monkey on rock at LL; praying mantis carrying wasp in front claws at R; valley landscape with cascades in background
markings: ULC, red square intaglio and square relief artist\'s seals: 江雲 {Kōun}, 雲斎 {Unsai}; LRC, red square relief seal: 筆硯精良人生至楽
signed: ULC: 南溟堂江雲巌皎寫 {Nanmei-dō Kōun Gankyō sha}
text: Nothing is known about the painter Iwai Kōun other than that he was born in Nagasaki, the only port town in Japan open to foreigners for trade and residence during the Edo period (1603–1868). Nagasaki paintings reflect a strong influence of Chinese art that arrived here on merchant ships. On the right of this painting, a praying mantis has caught a wasp which it is about to kill. The spectacle is observed by a monkey above in the tree, who is himself watched by another monkey on the far left.
title: Monkeys Watching a Praying Mantis Catching a Wasp
